statement.text: Aortic dissection is a life-threatening condition where a tear in the aortic intima allows blood to enter and separate the layers of the aortic wall, creating a 'false lumen' parallel to the native 'true lumen'. It is classified by the Stanford system: Type A involves the ascending aorta (requires emergency surgery) and Type B involves only the descending aorta (initially managed medically).
statement.formal: Aortic Dissection: Intimal tear → Blood enters media → Separation of wall layers → True lumen + False lumen | Stanford A: Ascending aorta involved (60-70%) → Surgical emergency | Stanford B: Ascending aorta NOT involved (30-40%) → Medical management ± intervention

explanation.intuition: Imagine the aortic wall as a multi-layered tube, like the skin of an onion. In dissection, blood tears through the inner layer and forces its way between the layers, creating a new channel (false lumen) alongside the original channel (true lumen). The blood rushing through this false lumen can extend the tear in either direction, potentially blocking branch arteries or rupturing through the outer wall.
explanation.key_insight: The critical distinction in aortic dissection is whether the ascending aorta is involved (Type A) or not (Type B). Type A is a surgical emergency because it can cause: (1) acute aortic regurgitation, (2) coronary malperfusion causing MI, (3) tamponade from rupture into pericardium, (4) stroke from arch vessel involvement. Without surgery, Type A mortality increases 1-2% per hour in the first 48 hours.
explanation.technical_details: The intimal tear typically occurs at points of maximum wall stress: the ascending aorta 2-3 cm above the aortic valve (65%) or just distal to the left subclavian artery (20-30%). The dissection propagates in an antegrade direction (following blood flow) in 70% of cases. The false lumen can: (1) remain patent with active blood flow, (2) thrombose partially or completely, (3) compress the true lumen causing malperfusion, or (4) rupture. Re-entry tears allow blood to flow back from false to true lumen.
common_misconceptions: Dissection is the same as aneurysm - they're distinct pathologies (though dissected aortas can become aneurysmal)
All dissections need emergency surgery - only Type A; uncomplicated Type B is managed medically
Dissection always causes chest pain - some present with syncope, stroke, or ischemic leg
CT shows everything - TEE is better for aortic regurgitation and coronary involvement

definitions_glossary.intima: Innermost layer of arterial wall, in direct contact with blood
definitions_glossary.media: Middle layer of arterial wall, contains smooth muscle and elastic tissue
definitions_glossary.true_lumen: Original, native channel of the aorta
definitions_glossary.false_lumen: New channel created by dissection within the aortic wall
definitions_glossary.entry_tear: Primary intimal tear where blood enters the wall
definitions_glossary.re_entry_tear: Secondary tear where blood exits back to true lumen
definitions_glossary.malperfusion: Inadequate blood supply to organs due to branch vessel compromise

type_a.definition: Any dissection involving the ascending aorta, regardless of entry site

type_b.definition: Dissection involving only the descending aorta (distal to left subclavian)

debakey_classification.type_i: Originates in ascending, propagates to descending
debakey_classification.type_iii: Originates in descending, IIIa = thoracic only, IIIb = extends to abdominal

definition.@value: Tear in aortic intima allowing blood to separate wall layers, creating a false lumen parallel to the true lumen

sources.citation: Hiratzka LF, et al. 2010 ACCF/AHA/AATS Guidelines for the Diagnosis and Management of Patients With Thoracic Aortic Disease. Circulation. 2010;121:e266-e369.

learning_objectives: Define aortic dissection and distinguish from aortic aneurysm
Explain the Stanford and DeBakey classification systems
Identify the critical difference between Type A and Type B
List major risk factors for aortic dissection
Understand the urgency of Type A dissection
common_errors: Delaying diagnosis by pursuing other workup
Not considering dissection in stroke or leg ischemia
Giving anticoagulation without ruling out dissection
clinical_pearls: Think dissection in any patient with sudden severe chest/back pain + hypertension
Type A = Ascending = Emergency surgery; Type B = Below = Medical management
BP discrepancy between arms is classic but only present in 20-30%
Mortality increases 1-2% per hour in Type A - don't delay for additional tests
